evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is resistant to defeaters as it is supported by multiple sources and consistent with known patterns of crew resource management failures.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors contributing to aviation incidents, including miscommunication and coordination failures.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew occurred during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 as documented in hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown inferred from absence of warnings and incident despite communication means being available
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordination preventing the incident
If the headset operator or wingman had effectively warned the tug crew

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows communication channels existed (H1), and some coordination occurred between tug instructor and trainee (H2, H3), but lack of warning from wingman or headset operator about impending collision (H8) suggests a breakdown in communication/coordination among crew during the event.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement explicitly describing a communication breakdown; inference based on lack of warnings and incident outcome

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of human factors contributing to aviation incidents, including miscommunication and coordination failures.

assumptions: The tug crew and headset operator are considered part of the 'crew' in the claim
Human factors key features include miscommunication and coordination failures as described
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and coordination with no miscommunication or failures
If the incident was caused solely by mechanical or environmental factors unrelated to human communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly indicates communication and coordination failures among crew, including insufficient visual signals and lack of warnings about the impending collision. H2 and H3 show role changes and ongoing communication attempts, while H9 confirms crew awareness but limited experience, supporting the claim that communication/coordination breakdown aligns with known human factors in aviation incidents.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited detail on exact communication exchanges and cockpit crew interactions

The TRP and clearance measurements are standard for this aircraft and location

defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were compliant and clearly visible, or if the tug driver had received adequate warnings to stop in time, this would change the assessment.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates that the visual signaling method to stop the tug was insufficient and no warnings were given before the collision (H8). The aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4), despite the known clearance at the TRP (H7). This suggests potential weaknesses in the assessment of environmental or marking deficiencies, making the assessment not fully robust or resistant to defeaters.

node.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs

Maintenance or inspection reports indicating mechanical linkage issues

node.statement: External factors such as noise or equipment malfunction impaired crew communication

assumptions: Visual signals are part of communication; their insufficiency implies some communication impairment
defeaters: Evidence of actual noise or equipment malfunction impairing communication
Direct reports of communication failure due to external factors

quotes.exact_quote: He suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

outcome.reasoning_summary: H8 indicates that communication signals (visual) were insufficient due to attention focus, implying some communication impairment, but no direct mention of noise or equipment malfunction impairing communication.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence of noise or equipment malfunction affecting communication; only indirect suggestion of communication difficulty due to visual signal limitations.
